Buttons.Title: Boutons
Buttons.Intro: Les boutons déclenchent une action ou permettent de naviguer vers une autre page. Ils ont de multiples styles et configurations selon les besoins variés. Ils attirent l’attention sur les actions que l’utilisateur doit effectuer pour progresser dans un flux.
Buttons.IntroAlert: Cet élément de l’interface utilisateur est actuellement disponible uniquement dans le prologiciel des styles. Il sera bientôt offert pour le progiciel des composantes.
Buttons.PrimaryText: Les boutons principaux sont utilisés pour mettre en évidence les actions les plus importantes dans toute expérience utilisateur. Éviter autant que possible d’utiliser plus d’un bouton principal dans la même section ou le même écran.
Buttons.SecondaryText: Les boutons secondaires sont les plus utilisés et ils sont utilisés lorsqu’une action requiert moins d’attention visuelle. Ils peuvent également être utilisés parallèlement à une action principale s’il y a deux options à présenter à l’utilisateur et que ces options nécessitent une hiérarchie différente.
Buttons.CriticalText: Les boutons critiques sont utilisés pour des actions de destruction comme la suppression du contenu fourni par l’utilisateur.
Buttons.PlainText: Les boutons simples peuvent être utilisés pour des actions qui nécessitent moins d’attention que celles des boutons principaux ou secondaires. Ils sont également utiles dans les situations où l’interface utilisateur est plus compacte. Ces boutons ne doivent pas être utilisés comme des liens. Utiliser les styles de texte des liens dans ces situations.
Buttons.HierarchyDoImgAlt: Une interface utilisateur utilisant plusieurs types de boutons. Il y a un bouton principal, un bouton secondaire et un bouton simple, pour créer une hiérarchie visuelle.
Buttons.HierarchyDontText: L’utilisation de plusieurs boutons principaux dans une même page ou section.
Buttons.HierarchyDontImgAlt: Une interface utilisateur utilisant plusieurs boutons principaux ne permet pas à l’utilisateur de savoir quelle action est la plus importante.
Buttons.DestructiveDoText: L’utilisation du bouton critique ou du bouton simple critique pour les actions destructives.
Buttons.DestructiveDoImgAlt: Une fenêtre modale avec deux options : annuler et supprimer. Le bouton de suppression est un bouton critique rouge.
Buttons.DestructiveDontText: D’autres types de boutons doivent être utilisés pour les actions destructives.
Buttons.DestructiveDontImgAlt: Une fenêtre modale avec deux options : annuler et supprimer. Le bouton de suppression est un bouton principal bleu foncé, ce qui est incorrect.
Buttons.PlainDoText: Utiliser des boutons simples pour permettre à l’utilisateur d’effectuer une action ou de naviguer dans l’application.
Buttons.PlainDoImgAlt: Une interface utilisateur de type formulaire avec des boutons simples utilisés pour naviguer entre les étapes du formulaire.
Buttons.PlainDontText: Utiliser des boutons simples pour lier l’utilisateur à d’autres pages ou sites Web. Dans ce cas, il faut utiliser les liens.
Buttons.PlainDontImgAlt: Un centre d’aide déterminé comme une ressource avec un bouton simple utilisé pour renvoyer l’utilisateur vers le site Web du centre d’aide.
Buttons.SpacingGroupsText: Un groupe de boutons est un ensemble de boutons qui ont une relation contextuelle. Pour créer une cohérence dans la façon dont ces actions sont liées visuellement, des règles cohérentes d’espacement doivent être suivies. Pour les grands groupes de boutons, il doit y avoir un espacement de 16 pixels entre les boutons. Pour les petits groupes de boutons, il doit y avoir un espacement de 12 pixels entre les boutons.
Buttons.SpacingGroupsImgAlt: Spécifications indiquant l’espacement acceptable entre les boutons. L’espacement est décrit dans le paragraphe ci-dessous.
Buttons.MinMaxWidthImgAlt: Spécifications affichant les largeurs minimales et maximales des composantes des boutons. Ces largeurs sont décrites dans la section suivante:
Buttons.MinMaxWidthText: Les boutons de grande taille ont une largeur maximale de 400 pixels et une largeur minimale de 64 pixels. Les petits boutons ont une largeur maximale de 400 pixels et une largeur minimale de 52 pixels.
Buttons.AnatomyImgAlt: Les parties qui constituent les composantes du bouton. Les parties sont décrites dans la section suivante:
Buttons.AnatomyBGText: Le remplissage du fond derrière l’étiquette et l’icône du bouton. Le rayon des boutons de petite et de grande taille est de 4 pixels.
Buttons.AnatomyIconText: Les icônes sont utilisées pour soutenir le contenu de l’étiquette du bouton. Elles sont facultatives et elles peuvent être affichées ou masquées à l’aide des configurations d’icônes.
Buttons.AnatomyLblText: L’étiquette fournit à l’utilisateur le contexte relatif à l’action que le bouton va effectuer.
Buttons.SpecsImgAlt: Spécifications affichant les mesures quant au remplissage et aux couches des composantes du bouton.
Buttons.SpecsText: le remplissage vertical du petit bouton avec une disposition fluide est de 8 pixels et le remplissage horizontal à l’intérieur du bouton est de 16 pixels. L’icône a une largeur et une hauteur de 20 pixels. Il y a 8 pixels entre l’icône et l’étiquette. La largeur de l’étiquette est dynamique selon le nombre de caractères qu’elle contient. Le remplissage vertical du grand bouton avec une disposition fluide est de 12 pixels et le remplissage horizontal à l’intérieur du bouton est de 20 pixels. L’icône a une largeur et une hauteur de 24 pixels. Il y a 8 pixels entre l’icône et l’étiquette. La largeur de l’étiquette est dynamique selon le nombre de caractères qu’elle contient. Le remplissage vertical du petit bouton avec une disposition fixe et le remplissage horizontal fluide basé sur la largeur fixe du bouton sont de 8 pixels. L’icône a une largeur et une hauteur de 20 pixels. Il y a 8 pixels entre l’icône et l’étiquette. La largeur de l’étiquette est dynamique selon le nombre de caractères qu’elle contient. Le remplissage vertical grand bouton avec une disposition fixe et le remplissage horizontal fluide basé sur la largeur fixe du bouton sont de 12 pixels. L’icône a une largeur et une hauteur de 24 pixels. Il y a 8 pixels entre l’icône et l’étiquette. La largeur de l’étiquette est dynamique selon le nombre de caractères qu’elle contient.
Buttons.CaseHeading: Utilisation de la majuscule sur les étiquettes
Buttons.CaseDoImgAlt: Utilisation de minuscules sur un bouton indiquant « Enregistrer les modifications ».
Buttons.CaseDoText: Utiliser des minuscules pour les étiquettes de boutons
Buttons.CaseDontImgAlt: Utilisation de la majuscule pour la première lettre du bouton indiquant « Enregistrer les modifications ».
Buttons.CaseDontText: Utiliser des majuscules pour la première lettre sur les étiquettes de boutons
Buttons.DescriptiveDoImgAlt: Un bouton dont l’étiquette indique « Afficher mes documents ».
Buttons.DescriptiveDoText: Rédiger des descriptions d’étiquettes de bouton correspondant à l’action que le bouton va effectuer.
Buttons.DescriptiveDontText: Rédiger des descriptions d’étiquettes de bouton qui sont statiques et qui ne décrivent pas une action.
Buttons.DescriptiveDontImgAlt: Un bouton dont l’étiquette indique « Documents ».
Buttons.FigmaDirectionsListItem1: Dans le panneau des ressources, faire glisser le composant « bouton » à partir de la bibliothèque des composants.
Buttons.FigmaDirectionsListItem4: Si une icône est utilisée, les concepteurs peuvent modifier le mot-clé de Font Awesome afin de mettre à jour l’icône du bouton pour n’importe quelle icône de Font Awesome.
Buttons.FigmaDirectionsImgAlt: Une capture d’écran du panneau de conception de Figma. Le panneau de conception affiche les options de configuration parmi lesquelles les concepteurs peuvent choisir lorsqu’ils personnalisent un bouton.
Buttons.AccessibilityColourText: Les boutons principaux ont un rapport de contraste des couleurs de 8,88 : 1 et répondent aux normes d’accessibilité AAA selon la version 2.1 des normes WCAG.
Buttons.AccessibilityKeyboardText: Les boutons sont élaborés à l’aide de l’élément bouton HTML original afin de garantir que les éléments interactifs sont accessibles sur le clavier et conformes aux normes AA de la version 2.1 des normes WCAG.

Utilities.Heading: Utilitaires
Utilities.Text: [FR] Utilities are re-usable tokens, variables, etc. that are applied consistently to elements and components throughout the entire design system. This creates consistency in how the design system’s foundations are applied and allows efficient and reliable design iterations to be made globally.
Utilities.TypographyText: L’échelle de caractères réduit le nombre de styles au minimum et elle est conçue pour assurer une hiérarchie visuelle efficace du contenu dans son ensemble. Les styles de texte comprennent des tailles de points, des hauteurs de lignes et des espacements de paragraphes qui répondent aux normes d’accessibilité AAA de la version 2.1 des normes WCAG.
Utilities.SpacingText: Unités d’espacement à appliquer comme remplissage ou comme marges dans l’interface utilisateur. Les options d’espacement sont limitées pour aider à créer une cohérence entre les espacements. Toutes les unités d’espacement sont en groupe de quatre pour respecter une grille de quatre pixels.
Utilities.BreakpointsText: Définir des points d’arrêt permet au contenu et à la conception de s’adapter afin de fournir la meilleure disposition possible pour la fenêtre d’affichage ou le périphérique. Utiliser les largeurs fréquentes des points d’arrêt pour assurer la cohérence de la mise en page. Les consommateurs du système de conception peuvent ajouter des points d’arrêt supplémentaires si nécessaire.
Utilities.ColourText: Les concepteurs ont le choix entre plusieurs couleurs pour assurer une communication claire, indiquer la fonctionnalité de l’interface utilisateur et fournir un contraste de couleurs conforme aux normes d’accessibilité. Le système de couleurs est conçu pour définir la signification de chaque couleur, permettre des changements de couleur globaux et garantir que chaque couleur utilisée provient du système.

Overview.Heading: Aperçu
Overview.Text: Le système de conception IRCC est une boîte à outils de conception et de code partagés qui fournit un langage visuel, des composants, des modèles et des directives, le tout dans une source de vérité centralisée qui permet aux équipes de produits de créer des expériences évolutives, accessibles et unifiées. Il est personnalisé pour l'expérience du client et de l'agent et permet aux équipes de créer efficacement des services numériques d'immigration cohérents.
Overview.DesignerText: Découvrez comment démarrer avec la bibliothèque Figma du système de conception IRCC.
Overview.DeveloperText: Découvrez comment commencer à mettre en œuvre le système de conception IRCC dans votre projet.
Overview.DeveloperPackageTxt: FR This package contains the theming functionality for the Journey Design System.

Designers.HeadingText: Si vous êtes un concepteur, commencez ici pour trouver tout ce dont vous avez besoin pour utiliser la bibliothèque Figma du système de conception.
Designers.AboutHeading: À propos de la bibliothèque de conception
Designers.AboutText1: Le système de conception consiste, en partie, d'une bibliothèque Figma. Il s'agit du principal outil à utiliser par les concepteurs et il leur permet de créer des conceptions compatibles avec le système. La bibliothèque de conception est un ensemble centralisé de fichiers Figma qui est géré par une équipe de système de conception de base. En connectant votre projet à la bibliothèque de conception, vos projets hériteront automatiquement des mises à jour, des améliorations et des nouvelles fonctionnalités publiées dans la bibliothèque de conception.
Designers.AboutText2: Figma est une plate-forme de conception collaborative conçue pour gérer les cas d'utilisation de l'interface utilisateur/UX et du système de conception. En savoir plus sur Figma ici ou parcourir la chaîne [FR] Figma’s Youtube channel de Figma pour vous familiariser avec le logiciel ou regarder des didacticiels.
Designers.AccessHeading: Demande d'accès à la bibliothèque de conception
Designers.AccessText1: La bibliothèque de conception est publiée en tant que bibliothèque d'équipe sur Figma. Il existe actuellement trois fichiers Figma à connecter à votre projet afin d'accéder au système de conception complet - Foundations, Components et Patterns. Voici les étapes pour y accéder :
Designers.AccessListItem1: Créez un compte Figma si vous n'en avez pas déjà un.
Designers.AccessListItem2: Envoyez un courriel à Matthew.Emond@cic.gc.ca et indiquez-nous le courriel que vous utilisez pour votre compte Figma. Vous recevrez une réponse dès que nous vous aurons accordé l'accès.
Designers.AccessListItem3: [FR] Once you have received confirmation that you have access, log into Figma with the email you provided.
Designers.AccessListItem4: Créez un nouveau fichier de conception ou ouvrez un projet existant.
Designers.AccessListItem5: Dans la barre latérale gauche, sélectionnez 'Assets', puis sélectionnez l'icône de la bibliothèque d'équipe.
Designers.AccessListItem6: Activez la bibliothèque d'équipe en sélectionnant la bascule à côté des bibliothèques “Foundations”, “Components” et “Patterns”.
Designers.AccessText2: Vous devriez maintenant avoir accès aux styles de couleurs et de texte, aux composants et aux modèles utilisateur.
Designers.AccessText3: Une fois que vous avez activé les bibliothèques d'équipe, vous recevrez automatiquement toutes les mises à jour ou ajouts aux styles et composants qui seront publiés à l'avenir.
Designers.FigmaImg1AltText: L'interface Figma utilisée pour connecter des bibliothèques de composants externes à un fichier Figma.
Designers.InstallFontsHeading: Installation des polices du système de conception
Designers.InstallFontsText1: Le système de conception utilise Lato, Inter et Font Awesome (police d'icônes). Lato et Inter sont des polices Google et devraient être automatiquement disponibles dans Figma dans le sélecteur de polices. Font Awesome a été défini comme une 'police partagée' pour notre plan d'organisation et devrait également être disponible automatiquement dans Figma dans le sélecteur de polices. Si vous n'êtes pas membre de l'organisation Figma 'IRCC - Journey Labs', vous devrez obtenir et installer une version payante de Font Awesome ou utiliser votre propre police d'icônes en combinaison avec ce système de conception.
Designers.InstallFontsLink: En savoir plus sur Font Awesome
Designers.UsingStylesHeading: Utilisation des styles du système de conception
Designers.UsingStylesText1: Une fois que vous vous êtes connecté aux bibliothèques Figma et que vous vous êtes assuré d'avoir accès aux bonnes polices dans Figma, vous êtes prêt à commencer à utiliser les styles de couleur et de texte du système.
Designers.UsingStylesStrokeText1: Pour appliquer une couleur de fond ou de trait :
Designers.UsingStylesStrokeListItem1: Assurez-vous d'avoir connecté la bibliothèque 'Foundations' à votre fichier Figma
Designers.UsingStylesStrokeListItem2: Sélectionnez le calque auquel vous souhaitez appliquer le style de couleur
Designers.UsingStylesStrokeListItem3: Dans le panneau de conception, cliquez sur l'icône de style (quatre points) et recherchez le style de couleur système que vous souhaitez appliquer sous les propriétés 'fill' et/ou 'stroke'
Designers.UsingStylesStrokeListItem4: Conseil de pro : utilisez le champ de recherche pour filtrer la liste des styles de couleur
Designers.UsingStylesStrokeText2: [FR] Click here to see a list of all colour tokens and how they apply. We will be adding a colours page to this documentation site for additional details and guidance.
Designers.UsingStylesStrokeImgAltText: L'interface Figma utilisée pour appliquer des styles de couleur à un calque.
Designers.UsingStylesTextText1: Pour appliquer un style de texte :
Designers.UsingStylesTextListItem1: Assurez-vous d'avoir connecté la bibliothèque 'Foundations' à votre fichier Figma
Designers.UsingStylesTextListItem2: Sélectionnez le calque de texte auquel vous souhaitez définir le style de texte
Designers.UsingStylesTextListItem3: Dans le panneau de conception, cliquez sur l'icône de style (quatre points) et recherchez le style de texte système que vous souhaitez appliquer sous la propriété 'text'.
Designers.UsingStylesTextListItem4: Conseil de pro : utilisez le champ de recherche pour filtrer la liste des styles de texte
Designers.UsingStylesTextText2: [FR] Click here to see a list of all text tokens and how they apply. We will be adding a typography page to this documentation site for additional details and guidance.
Designers.UsingStylesTextImgAltText: L'interface Figma utilisée pour appliquer des styles de texte à un calque de texte.
Designers.UsingComponentsHeading: Utilisation des composants du système de conception
Designers.UsingComponentsText1: Une fois que vous vous êtes connecté aux bibliothèques Figma et que vous vous êtes assuré d'avoir accès aux bonnes polices dans Figma, vous êtes prêt à commencer à utiliser les composants du système.
Designers.UsingComponentsInsertText1: Pour insérer un composant système dans votre fichier de conception :
Designers.UsingComponentsInsertListItem1: Assurez-vous d'avoir connecté les bibliothèques 'Components' et 'Patterns' à votre fichier Figma
Designers.UsingComponentsInsertListItem2: Dans le panneau de gauche, cliquez sur l'onglet 'Assets'

Input.Title: Input
Input.Intro: The input component provides fields that allow users to enter information. The input component provides several configurable options to clearly communicate form requirements for many use-cases.
Input.PrimaryText: The basic input allows for entry of single-line information. The form component is configurable to fit various use cases and layouts. See available configurations below.
Input.SecondaryText: The password input allows users to enter their password. The password can be hidden or shown.
Input.FieldWidthImgDo: A wide input field for typing a country name and a narrow input field for typing a year.
Input.FieldWidthDoText: Use field widths that are appropriate for the type of content being gathered.
Input.FieldWidthImgDont: A narrow input field for typing a country name and a wide input field for typing a year.
Input.FieldWidthDontText: Use arbitrary field widths that are not sized based on the width of the expected value.
Input.ErrorDoImgAlt: An input field that shows validation by highlighting the field red with an error message underneath.
Input.ErrorDoText: Show the error visual treatment on the field in addition to showing the error message when showing error validation.
Input.ErrorDontImgAlt: An input field that only uses an error message as validation.
Input.ErrorDontText: Only show the error message when showing error validation.
Input.MaxMinWidthImgAlt: An input field that shows small inputs have a maximum width of 552 pixels and a minimum width of 92 pixels. Large inputs have a maximum width of 632 pixels and a minimum width of 104 pixels.
Input.MaxMinWidthText: Small inputs have a maximum width of 552 pixels and a minimum width of 92 pixels. Large inputs have a maximum width of 632 pixels and a minimum width of 104 pixels.
Input.AnatomyImgAlt: The parts that makeup the input component. The parts are described in the content below.
Input.AnatomyInputFieldText: The area that the user interacts with to input content.
Input.AnatomyInputContentText: The content that the user inputs into the field. The field also supports optional placeholder text that displays before the user inputs text.
Input.AnatomyPasswordText: The password field allows users to enter their password. The password can be hidden or shown.
Input.SpecsImgAlt: Specs displaying the padding and layer measurements within the input component. Specs are described in the paragraph below.
Input.SpecsImgDesc1: The small basic input’s label is 24 pixels in height with a fluid width. The required indicator is 12 pixels wide. There are 4 pixels of padding between the required indicator and the label. The description is 20 pixels in height with a fluid width. There are 4 pixels of padding between the label and the description. The hint text is 20 pixels in height with a fluid width. There are 8 pixels of padding between the hint text and the description. The input field is 40 pixels in height with a fixed width.  There are 4 pixels of padding between the input field and the hint text. The error message is 20 pixels in height with a fluid width. The error icon is 16 by 16 pixels. There are 4 pixels of padding between the error icon and the error message. There are 4 pixels of padding between the error message and the input field. The small password field is 40 pixels tall with a fixed width. There are 12 pixels of padding within the input field. The password text is fluid in width. The hide/show password icon is 16 pixels wide. There are 4 pixels of padding between the hide/show password icon and the password text.
Input.SpecsImgDesc2: The large basic input’s label is 28 pixels in height with a fluid width. The required indicator is 16 pixels wide. There are 4 pixels of padding between the required indicator and the label. The description is 24 pixels in height with a fluid width. There are 4 pixels of padding between the label and the description. The hint text is 24 pixels in height with a fluid width. There are 12 pixels of padding between the hint text and the description. The input field is 52 pixels in height with a fixed width.  There are 8 pixels of padding between the input field and the hint text. The error message is 24 pixels in height with a fluid width. The error icon is 20 by 20 pixels. There are 4 pixels of padding between the error icon and the error message. There are 4 pixels of padding between the error message and the input field. The large password field is 52 pixels tall with a fixed width. There are 12 pixels of padding within the input field. The password text is fluid in width. The hide/show password icon is 20 pixels wide. There are 4 pixels of padding between the hide/show password icon and the password text.
Input.WriteLabelsSubHeading: Labels are mandatory content for the input component. Labels make the purpose of the field clear.
Input.WriteLabelsDoImgAlt1: An input field to collect the user’s full name. The label is “Full name (required)”. The description is “Provide your name as it appears on your passport, travel or identity document.” The input field is empty.
Input.WriteLabelsDoText1: Write labels that are appropriate for the task and clear.
Input.WriteLabelsDontImgAlt1: An input field to collect the user’s full name. The label is “Full name (required)”. There is no description. The input field is empty.
Input.WriteLabelsDontText1: Rely on the label to do the whole job of informing a user of the task to perform.
Input.WriteLabelsDoImgAlt2: An input field to collect the user’s email address. The label is “Email address (required)”. The input field is empty.
Input.WriteLabelsDoText2: Keep labels as clear and short as possible.
Input.WriteLabelsDontImgAlt2: An input field to collect the user’s email address. The label is “What is your primary email address? (required)”. The input field is empty.
Input.WriteLabelsDontText2: Write hard to understand and longer than necessary labels.
Input.WriteDescSubHeading: Write a complete description of the action a user is to perform. Include all the relevant information required, but try to keep the description concise.
Input.WriteDescDoImgAlt: An input field to collect the user’s Family name. The label is “Family name (required)”. The input field is empty.
Input.WriteDescDoText: Include all the relevant information in the description.
Input.WriteDescDontImgAlt: An input field to collect the user’s email address. The label is “Email address (required)”. The input field is empty.
Input.WriteDescDontText: Include a description when additional instructions or details are not needed to clarify how to correctly fill out the field.
Input.WritePlaceholderSubHeading: Placeholder text appears in the input field. Use it only where it is needed to accelerate a user’s understanding of the information they need to provide. Placeholder text can either be an example of the type of expected value that is to be entered or to show the exact format of what is to be entered.
Input.WritePlaceholderDoImgAlt1: An input field to collect the user’s student identification number. The label is “Student identification number (required)”. The description is “Enter your 9 digit ID number found in your profile.” The input field has placeholder text within it. The placeholder text is “Ex: 301297423”
Input.WritePlaceholderDoText1: Provide placeholder text as a specific example of the expected value, within an input field.
Input.WritePlaceholderDontImgAlt1: An input field to collect the user’s email address. The label is “Email address (required)”. The input field has placeholder text within it. The placeholder text is “johnsmith@email.com”
Input.WritePlaceholderDontText1: Use placeholder text when the expected value is already obvious to the user or where the example makes it seem like the field has already been completed.
Input.WritePlaceholderDoImgAlt2: An input field to collect the user’s date of birth. The label is “Date of birth (required)”. There are three fields for year, month and day. The input fields have placeholder text within them. The placeholder text for year is “YYYY”. The placeholder text for month is “month”. The placeholder text for day is “DD”.
Input.WritePlaceholderDoText2: Provide placeholder text to show the exact required format, within an input field.
Input.WritePlaceholderDontImgAlt2: An input field to collect the user’s date of birth. The label is “Date of birth (required)”. There are three fields for year, month and day. The input fields have placeholder text where hint text is supposed to be used. The placeholder text for year is “YYYY”. The placeholder text for month is “month”. The placeholder text for day is “DD”.
Input.WritePlaceholderDontText2: Substitute hint text with placeholder text.
Input.WriteErrorsSubHeading: Error messages inform a user of missing or incorrect information. Write error messages to be helpful, allowing a user to correct their omissions or mistakes.
Input.WriteErrorsDoImgAlt: An input field to collect the user’s family name. The label is “Family name (required)”. The description is “This is your surname or last name.” The error message is “This field is blank. Please enter a family name.”
Input.WriteErrorsDoText: Provide error text that is helpful and guides the user as to what to correct.
Input.WriteErrorsDontImgAlt: An input field to collect the user’s family name. The label is “Family name (required)”. The description is “This is your surname or last name.” The error message is “Error. Field is required.”
Input.WriteErrorsDontText: Write error messages that sound like a robot.
Input.NecessaryContentDoImgAlt: An input field to collect the user’s country. The label is “Country where you were born (required)”. The input field is empty.
Input.NecessaryContentDoText: Only use necessary content layers. Not every field needs a label, description, hint and placeholder text.
Input.NecessaryContentDontImgAlt: An input field to collect the user’s country. The label is “Country where you were born (required)”. The description is “The country  you were born in”. The input field’s placeholder text is “Ex: France”.
Input.NecessaryContentDontText: Add unnecessary or redundant content layers to the input.
Input.RequiredFieldsDoImgAlt: An input field to collect the user’s job title. The label is “Job title (required)”. The input field is empty.
Input.RequiredFieldsDoText: In addition to using the required asterisk (*), also add “(required)” at the end of all labels within required fields.
Input.RequiredFieldsDontImgAlt: An input field to collect the user’s job title. The label is “Job title”. The input field is empty.
Input.RequiredFieldsDontText: Indicate required fields with only the asterisk (*).
Input.FigmaDirectionsListItem1: From the “Assets” panel, drag in the “form-input” component from the Components library.
Input.FigmaDirectionsListItem4: Never override the asterisk (*) or error icons in order to keep those visual indicators consistent.
Input.FigmaDirectionsImgAlt: A screenshot of the design panel from Figma. The design panel displays the configuration options designers can choose from when customizing a input. These options allow designers to hide or show the required asterisk, description, hint, count and error text.
Input.AccessInputsHeading: To access the input field’s states
Input.AccessInputsListItem1: Click into the input-field subcomponent inside of the form-input component in the Layers palette (left panel).
Input.AccessInputsListItem2: From there, you can configure the input field’s content and states in the right panel.
Input.AccessInputsImgAlt1: A screenshot of the layer panel from Figma. The selected layer displayed is the “input-field” subcomponent within the “form-input” component.
Input.AccessInputsImgAlt2: A screenshot of the design panel from Figma. With the “input-field” subcomponent selected, designers can choose from its configuration options. These options include the type of field, the type of content populated within the field, whether the field is in an error state and the state of the field.
Input.AccessibilityColourText: All elements within the input component have a colour contrast ratio of 4.5:1 and passes AA accessibility standards under WCAG 2.1.
Input.AccessibilityKeyboardText: Inputs are developed using the native HTML input element to ensure interactive elements are keyboard accessible and pass WCAG 2.1 AA conformity. The input can be navigated to and interacted with using a keyboard and receives a visible focus.
Input.AccessibilityContentItem2: Headings and labels describe topic or purpose.
Input.AccessibilityContentItem3: Labels or instructions are provided when content requires user input.
Input.AccessibilityContentItem4: The label, description and hint are placed outside of the form field and are always visible to the user. The content is presented in a logical reading order.
Input.AccessibilityContentItem5: Label that includes an asterisk to indicate the control is required.
Input.AccessibilityContentItem6: Clear labelling for required fields, including the word “required” in parentheses.
Input.AccessibilityValidationText: If an input error is automatically detected, the item that is in error is identified and the error is described to the user in text.
Input.CodeViewer: Code viewer block displaying the html and typescript code generated from the interactive demo

DatePicker.Title: [FR] DatePicker-doc
DatePicker.Intro: [FR] The date picker component allows users to input a specific year, month and/or day.

DesignGuideLines.MaintainDoAlt: [FR] A small date picker in the horizontal layout with consistent widths.
DesignGuideLines.MaintainDoText: [FR] Maintain the default width of each select dropdown. They are intentionally sized to fit the “unknown” option.
DesignGuideLines.MaintainDontAlt: [FR] A small date picker in the horizontal layout is best used for the mobile.
DesignGuideLines.MaintainDontText: [FR] Alter the fixed width of the select dropdowns.
DesignGuideLines.ErrorValidationDoAlt: [FR] Date picker field that show validation by highlighting the field red with three error messages underneath.
DesignGuideLines.ErrorValidationDo: [FR] Show both the error visual treatment on the appropriate select dropdown(s), as well as the error message when displaying error validation to the user.
DesignGuideLines.ErrorValidationDontAlt: [FR] Date picker fields that show validation by only displaying error messages underneath.
DesignGuideLines.ErrorValidationDont: [FR] Only display the error message when showing error validation to the user.
DesignGuideLines.Horizontal: [FR] Use horizontal layout when you have the room
DesignGuideLines.HorizontalDoAlt: [FR] Date picker field that show validation by highlighting the field red with three error messages underneath.
DesignGuideLines.HorizontalDo: [FR] Use the horizontal layout when the parent container is wide. Use the vertical layout when the parent container is narrow. The most common place for using vertical is within mobile mockups.
DesignGuideLines.HorizontalDontAlt: [FR] Date picker fields that is in vertical layout when the parent container is wide.
DesignGuideLines.HorizontalDont: [FR] Use horizontal layout when your form is in a narrow container. Don’t use the vertical layout when you form is in a wide container.

Anatomy.ImgAlt: [FR] The parts that makeup the date picker component. The parts are described in the content below.
Anatomy.SelectCompoTxt: [FR] The area that the user interacts with to open up a dropdown menu for date selection. The select also supports placeholder text that displays before the user makes a selection.

Specs.ImgAlt: [FR] Specs displaying the padding and layer measurements within the date picker component. Specs are described in the paragraph below.
Specs.Text1: [FR] The small horizontal date picker has 396 pixels fixed width and default height is 172 pixels and hugs content. The label text is 24 pixels in height with a fluid width. The required indicator is 12 pixels wide. There are 4 pixels of padding between the required indicator and the label. The description is 20 pixels in height with a fluid width. There are 4 pixels of padding between the label and the description. The hint text is 20 pixels in height with a fluid width. There are 8 pixels of padding between the hint text and the description. There are 4 pixels of padding between the hint text and the fields. Each field has consistent widths of 124 pixels, heights of 68 pixels and horizontal padding of 12 pixels. There are 4 pixels between the The dropdown icon has a 16 pixel width and height. The large horizontal date picker has 396 pixels fixed width and default height is 220 pixels and hugs content. The label text is 28 pixels in height with a fluid width. The required indicator is 12 pixels wide. There are 4 pixels of padding between the required indicator and the label. The description is 24 pixels in height with a fluid width. There are 4 pixels of padding between the label and the description. The hint text is 24 pixels in height with a fluid width. There are 12 pixels of padding between the hint text and the description. There are 8 pixels of padding between the hint text and the fields. Each field has consistent widths of 136 pixels, heights of 88 pixels and horizontal padding of 12 pixels. There are 4 pixels The dropdown icon has a 16 pixel width and height.
Specs.Text2: [FR] The small vertical date picker has 152 pixels fixed width and default height is 332 pixels and hugs content. The label text is 24 pixels in height with a fluid width. The required indicator is 12 pixels wide. There are 4 pixels of padding between the required indicator and the label. The description is 20 pixels in height with a fluid width. There are 4 pixels of padding between the label and the description. The hint text is 20 pixels in height with a fluid width. There are 8 pixels of padding between the hint text and the description. There are 4 pixels of padding between the hint text and the fields. Each field has consistent widths of 162 pixels, heights of 68 pixels and vertical padding of 12 pixels. The large vertical date picker has 420 pixels fixed width and default height is 148 pixels and hugs content. The label text is 28 pixels in height with a fluid width. The required indicator is 12 pixels wide. There are 4 pixels of padding between the required indicator and the label. The description is 24 pixels in height with a fluid width. There are 4 pixels of padding between the label and the description. The hint text is 24 pixels in height with a fluid width. There are 12 pixels of padding between the hint text and the description. There are 8 pixels of padding between the hint text and the fields. Each field has consistent widths of 220 pixels, heights of 88 pixels and horizontal padding of 12 pixels.

ContentGuideLines.CorrectOrderDoAlt: [FR] Date picker fields are in the correct labelling order YYYY-Month-DD.
ContentGuideLines.CorrectOrderDo: [FR] Ensure the date picker selects are in the order of YYYY-Month-DD.
ContentGuideLines.CorrectOrderDontAlt: [FR] Date picker fields shown are in incorrect labelling order Month-DD-YYYY.
ContentGuideLines.CorrectOrderDont: [FR] Change the order of the date picker selects. The order should be YYYY-Month-DD.
ContentGuideLines.WritingLabelsTxt: [FR] Labels are mandatory content for the date picker component. Labels make the purpose of the date picker clear.
ContentGuideLines.WritingLabelsDoAlt: [FR] Date picker fields with the “Date of birth (required)” label.
ContentGuideLines.WritingLabelsDo: [FR] Keep labels as clear and short as possible.
ContentGuideLines.WritingLabelsDontAlt: [FR] Date picker fields with “The day you were born” label.
ContentGuideLines.WritingLabelsDont: [FR] Write labels that are difficult to understand or labels that are longer than necessary.
ContentGuideLines.PlaceholderHeading: [FR] Use placeholder text within the select dropdowns
ContentGuideLines.PlaceholderDoAlt: [FR] Date picker fields with the “Date of birth” label and placeholder text within fields.
ContentGuideLines.PlaceholderDo: [FR] Provide placeholder text to show the exact required format, within a select dropdown.
ContentGuideLines.PlaceholderDontAlt: [FR] A date picker that has no placeholder text inside of the select dropdowns.
ContentGuideLines.PlaceholderDont: [FR] Remove placeholder text from the select dropdowns.
ContentGuideLines.WritingErrTxt: [FR] Error messages inform a user of missing or incorrect information. Write error messages to be helpful, allowing a user to correct their omissions or mistakes.
ContentGuideLines.WritingErrDoAlt: [FR] A date picker to collect the user’s date of birth. The label is “Date of birth (required)”.  The error message is “This field is blank. Please enter a date of birth.”
ContentGuideLines.WritingErrDo: [FR] Provide error text that is helpful and guides the user as to what to correct.
ContentGuideLines.WritingErrDontAlt: [FR] A date picker to collect the user’s date of birth. The label is “Date of birth (required)”. The error message is “Error. Field is required.”
ContentGuideLines.WritingErrDont: [FR] Write error messages that sound like a robot.
ContentGuideLines.NecessaryContentDoAlt: [FR] A date picker fields collect a user’s date of birth with the “Date of birth (required)” label.
ContentGuideLines.NecessaryContentDo: [FR] Only use necessary content layers. Not every field needs a label, description, hint and placeholder text.
ContentGuideLines.NecessaryContentDontAlt: [FR] A date picker fields collect a user’s date of birth  The label is “Date of birth (required)”. The description is “The day you were born.”
ContentGuideLines.NecessaryContentDont: [FR] Add unnecessary or redundant content layers to the input.
ContentGuideLines.RequiredFieldsDoAlt: [FR] A date picker fields collect a user’s date of birth with the “Date of birth (required)” label.
ContentGuideLines.RequiredFieldsDo: [FR] In addition to using the required asterisk (*), also add “(required)” at the end of all labels within required fields.
ContentGuideLines.RequiredFieldsDontAlt: [FR] A date picker fields collect a user’s date of birth with the “Date of birth” label.
ContentGuideLines.RequiredFieldsDont: [FR] Indicate required fields with only the asterisk (*).

UsageInFigma.FigmaDirectionsListItem1: [FR] From the “Assets” panel, drag in the “date-picker” component from the Patterns library.
UsageInFigma.FigmaDirectionsListItem4: [FR] Never override the asterisk (*) or error icons in order to keep those visual indicators consistent.
UsageInFigma.AccessInputsHeading: [FR] To access the input field’s state
UsageInFigma.FigmaDirectionsSecondItem1: [FR] Click into the input-field subcomponent inside of the form-input component in the Layers palette (left panel).
UsageInFigma.FigmaDirectionsSecondItem2: [FR] From there, you can configure the input field’s content and states in the right panel.

These options include size and layout of the component,  allow designers to hide or show the required asterisk, description, hint, field 2, field 3 and error message.

Accessibility.ColorContrastTxt: [FR] All elements within the date picker component have a colour contrast ratio of 4.5:1 and passes AA accessibility standards under WCAG 2.1.
Accessibility.KeyboardAccessibleTxt: [FR] Date pickers are developed using the native HTML input element to ensure interactive elements are keyboard accessible and pass WCAG 2.1 AA conformity. The input can be navigated to and interacted with using a keyboard and receives a visible focus.
Accessibility.ColorText4: [FR] Success banners have a colour contrast ratio of 16.86:1 and passes AAA accessibility standards under WCAG 2.1.
Accessibility.ColorText5: [FR] Generic banners have a colour contrast ratio of 16.6:1 and passes AAA accessibility standards under WCAG 2.1.
Accessibility.KeyboardText: [FR] Banners are developed using the native HTML button element to ensure interactive elements are keyboard accessible and pass WCAG 2.1 AA conformity.
Accessibility.ContentTxt2: [FR] Headings and labels describe topic or purpose.
Accessibility.ContentTxt3: [FR] Labels or instructions are provided when content requires user input.
Accessibility.ContentTxt4: [FR] The label, description and hint are placed outside of the form field and are always visible to the user. The content is presented in a logical reading order.
Accessibility.ContentTxt5: [FR] Label that includes an asterisk to indicate the control is required.
Accessibility.ContentTxt6: [FR] Clear labelling for required fields, including the word “required” in parentheses.

DatePicker.Validation: [FR] If a date picker error is automatically detected, the item that is in error is identified and the error is described to the user in text.

RequestForm.Title: Submit a request
RequestForm.Intro: Some intro about what this is used for. Change requests, feature requests, bugs, etc.
RequestForm.BannerDesc: This form is submitted toIRCC.JLDS-JLSDC.IRCC@cic.gc.cawhich is viewed by the design system team. We will review and respond to your request as soon as possible.
RequestForm.requestCriteriaSubText1: A request should show that the contribution to the system would be useful and unique.
RequestForm.requestCriteriaSubText2: There is evidence that this component or pattern would be useful for many teams or services.
RequestForm.requestCriteriaSubText3: It does not replicate something already in the Design System. If it’s intended to replace an existing component or pattern, there is evidence to show that it’s better than the existing version and solves existing use cases.
RequestForm.radioOption1: Change request (modifying or adding to an existing system part)
RequestForm.radioOption2: Feature request (Defining and creating na new system part)
RequestForm.radioOption3: Bug (A system part that is not functioning as intended)
RequestForm.requestTitleDesc: Enter a brief title that represents the feature, change or bug.
RequestForm.requestDetailsDesc: Describe the feature, change or bug.
RequestForm.useCaseDesc: Describe the use case(s) that you are currently unable to satisfy with the design system.
RequestForm.referencesCaseDesc: Include any URLs you may have that we can view as reference. This can be website links or Figma design links, etc.
RequestForm.referencesHint: We currently are unable to support attachments
RequestForm.requestedDateLabel: When is the completed work needed by? (required)
RequestForm.requestedDateDesc: When would you need the work delivered in order for your team to start implementation into your project?
RequestForm.requiredDateError: Please fill in the missing fields

Banner.Title: [FR] Banners
Banner.Intro: [FR] Banners provide valuable supporting content to the user conveying a specific sentiment (warning, success, informational, etc.) and can be used to help the user complete a task or better understand the content they are viewing.
Banner.InfoPrimaryText: [FR] Info banners are used to convey important general information.
Banner.WarningPrimaryText: W[FR] arning banners are used to convey important warnings.
Banner.CriticalPrimaryText: [FR] Critical banners are used to convey critical information or errors.
Banner.SuccessPrimaryText: [FR] Success banners are used to convey successful actions or validations.
Banner.GenericPrimaryText: [FR] Generic banners are used when an alert sentiment is not appropriate for displaying a message to the user.

BannerPreview.Content: [FR] Description text lorem ipsum dolor sit amet consecteteur adipiscing elit.

DesignGuideLines.BannerActionsDoAlt: [FR] A banner that has the label “Minor in Canada” and description text with a “Clear this section” CTA button. The banner uses the teal info styling.
DesignGuideLines.BannerActionsDontAlt: [FR] A banner that has the label “Duplicate file name” and description text written in title case with two CTAs - “Delete file” and “Keep file”. The banner uses the orange warning styling.
DesignGuideLines.BannerActionsDoText: [FR] Use the banner for simple actions that are not critical to the user’s workflow.
DesignGuideLines.BannerActionsDontText: [FR] Make the user perform important or critical actions from within a banner. Banners should provide supplementary content and actions that help them understand the surrounding page/task.
DesignGuideLines.UseOneBannerAtATimeLabel: [FR] Use one banner at a time
DesignGuideLines.BannerCountDoAlt: [FR] A banner that has the label “Duplicate file name” and description text. The banner uses the orange warning styling.
DesignGuideLines.BannerCountDontAlt: [FR] There are two banners that have the label “Duplicate file name” and “You don’t need to provide medical exam” along with description text. The first banner uses the orange warning styling. The second banner uses the green success styling.
DesignGuideLines.BannerCountDoText: [FR] Only show one banner at a time in the same section.
DesignGuideLines.BannerCountDontText: [FR] Do not stack multiple banners together.
DesignGuideLines.ShowMaximumButtonsLabel: [FR] Show maximum three buttons at a time
DesignGuideLines.bannerButtonCountDoAlt: [FR] A banner that has the label “Proof of relationship” and description text. It is displaying two CTA buttons and one external link. The banner uses the teal info styling.
DesignGuideLines.bannerButtonCountDontAlt: [FR] A banner that has the label “Duplicate file name” and description text. It is displaying four CTA buttons. The banner uses the orange warning styling.
DesignGuideLines.bannerButtonCountDoText: [FR] Show maximum three CTA buttons at time.
DesignGuideLines.bannerButtonCountDontText: [FR] Do not apply more than three CTA buttons in a banner.
DesignGuideLines.ProperButtonTypeInGroupLabel: [FR] Use the proper button type in button groups
DesignGuideLines.bannerButtonTypeDoAlt: [FR] A banner that has the label “Change your physical presence calculation” and description text with two options - secondary button that says  “Update physical presence” and plain button “Later”. The banner uses the orange warning styling.
DesignGuideLines.bannerButtonTypeDontAlt: [FR] A banner that has the label “Change your physical presence calculation” and description text with two options - two secondary button that says “Update physical presence” and “Later”. The banner uses the orange warning styling.
DesignGuideLines.bannerButtonTypeDontText: [FR] Use the same button type next to another leading to a lack of hierarchy.
DesignGuideLines.BannerCorrectDismissLabel: [FR] Use the correct button to dismiss a banner
DesignGuideLines.bannerDismissDoAlt: [FR] A banner that has the label “You’re almost done with your profile” and description text with a close icon button. The banner uses the teal info styling.
DesignGuideLines.bannerDismissDontAlt: [FR] A banner that has the label “You’re almost done with your profile” and description text with a CTA button that says “Dismiss”. The banner uses the teal info styling.
DesignGuideLines.bannerDismissDoText: [FR] Use the close icon button to close the banner.
DesignGuideLines.bannerDismissDontText: [FR] Don’t use CTA button to close the banner.
DesignGuideLines.bannerMinMaxWidthAlt: [FR] Specs displaying the minimum and maximum widths of the banner component. Widths are described in the paragraph below.
DesignGuideLines.bannerMinMaxWidthText: [FR] Small banners have a maximum width of 600 pixels and a minimum width of 300 pixels. Large banners have a maximum width of 680 pixels and a minimum width of 340 pixels.

Anatomy.ImgAlt: [FR] The parts that makeup the banner component. The parts are described in the content below.
Anatomy.ContainerText: [FR] The boundary of the banner. The container can display various styles and can be set to any desired fixed width.
Anatomy.BannerIconTypeText: [FR] Icon indicating the type / sentiment of the banner.
Anatomy.BannerBarText: [FR] Visual element used to highlight the banner’s content.
Anatomy.CTAGroupText: [FR] Group of actions that the user can interact with related to the banner content.

Specs.ImgAlt: [FR] Specs displaying the padding and layer measurements within the banner component. Specs are described in the paragraph below.
Specs.Text: [FR] The small banner with fluid layout has 12 pixels of vertical padding and 12 pixels of horizontal padding inside the banner. The icon has a 20-pixel width and height. There are 12 pixels between the icon and banner-content. The layout of the content within the banner adjusts based on the container’s width. The height of the banner is fluid and adjusts based on the amount of content within the banner. The large banner with fluid layout has 16 pixels of vertical padding and 16 pixels of horizontal padding inside the button. The icon has a 24-pixel width and height. There are 12 pixels between the icon and label. The layout of the content within the banner adjusts based on the container’s width. The height of the banner is fluid and adjusts based on the amount of content within the banner.

ContentGuideLines.UseCorrectCaseHeading: [FR] Use the correct case for titles
ContentGuideLines.BannerUseCorrectCaseDoAlt: [FR] A banner that has the label “Title text” and description text written in sentence case. The banner uses the blue info styling.
ContentGuideLines.BannerUseCorrectCaseDontAlt: [FR] A banner that has the label “Title text” and description text written in title case. The banner uses the blue info styling.
ContentGuideLines.BannerUseCorrectCaseDontText: [FR]  Write banner title and description in title case.
ContentGuideLines.BannerTitleDoAlt: [FR] A banner that has the label “you don’t need to provide medical exam” and description text. The banner uses the green success styling.
ContentGuideLines.BannerTitleDontAlt: [FR] A banner that has the label “After thorough verification, we have determined you don’t need to provide medical exam.” and description text. The banner uses the green success styling.
ContentGuideLines.BannerPunctuationDoAlt: [FR] A banner that has the label “Minor in Canada” and description text. The banner uses the teal info styling.
ContentGuideLines.BannerPunctuationDontAlt: [FR] A banner that has the label “Minor in Canada.” and description text. The banner uses the teal info styling.
ContentGuideLines.BannerPunctuationDoText: [FR] Include period at the end of the description to indicate end of a sentence.
ContentGuideLines.BannerPunctuationDontText: [FR] Include period in title and must include period in description, otherwise the sentence may seem unfinished.

UsageInFigma.FigmaDirectionsImgAlt: [FR] A screenshot of the design panel from Figma. The design panel displays the configuration options designers can choose from when customizing a banner.
UsageInFigma.FigmaDirectionsListItem1: [FR] From the “Assets” panel, drag in the “banner” component from the Components library.
UsageInFigma.FigmaDirectionsListItem4: [FR] Use one or multiple CTA buttons within the banner by toggling on the “Show CTA1” property.

Accessibility.ColorText1: [FR] Info banners have a colour contrast ratio of 16.6:1 and passes AAA accessibility standards under WCAG 2.1.
Accessibility.ColorText2: [FR] Warning banners have a colour contrast ratio of 16.45:1 and passes AAA accessibility standards under WCAG 2.1.
Accessibility.ColorText3: [FR] Critical banners have a colour contrast ratio of 15.85:1 and passes AAA accessibility standards under WCAG 2.1.
Accessibility.ColorText4: [FR] Success banners have a colour contrast ratio of 16.86:1 and passes AAA accessibility standards under WCAG 2.1.
Accessibility.ColorText5: [FR] Generic banners have a colour contrast ratio of 16.6:1 and passes AAA accessibility standards under WCAG 2.1.
Accessibility.KeyboardText: [FR] Banners are developed using the native HTML button element to ensure interactive elements are keyboard accessible and pass WCAG 2.1 AA conformity.

BannerConfig.CTA2Label: [FR] CTA 2 (if CTA 1 is set to true)
BannerConfig.CTA3Label: [FR] CTA 3 (if CTA 1 is set to true)

General.Label: [FR] Label Text
General.ButtonTypeDoText: [FR] Create a visual hierarchy by properly utilizing button types. The button types chosen should feel appropriate for the action they are being assigned to.
General.FigmaDirectionsListItem2: [FR] In the right panel, configure the properties and variants to meet your needs.
General.FigmaDirectionsListItem3: Ne jamais modifier les couleurs, le rayon, le remplissage, la taille du texte, etc. De cette façon, les éléments fondamentaux restent cohérents.
General.RequiredIndicatorTxt: [FR] Indicates which fields are mandatory to successfully submit the form.
General.AnatomyLabelText: [FR] The label makes the purpose of the field clear.
General.AnatomyDescText: [FR] The description includes the action a user is to perform as well as all the relevant information required.
General.AnatomyHintText: [FR] The hint is used to display secondary or tertiary information. It is only used when the label and description will not suffice in helping the user understand the input.
General.AnatomyErrorText: [FR] The error text that displays if the field is in an invalid state.
General.AccessibilityContentItem1: [FR] Information, structure, and relationships conveyed through presentation can be programmatically determined or are available in text.
General.AccessibilityContentItemMax: [FR] Max widths are determined based on allowing a maximum line length of 80 characters.
General.InteractiveDemoDesc: Try our {{component}} component and the configurable options available within it.

IconButtonDocumentation.Title: [FR] Icon Button
IconButtonDocumentation.Intro: [FR] Icon buttons can be used for a single, well-understood action that can be clearly communicated with a stand-alone icon.
IconButtonDocumentation.PrimaryText: [FR] Primary icon buttons are used to highlight important and easy-to-understand actions. It can be used in a group of icon buttons.
IconButtonDocumentation.CriticalText: [FR] Critical icon buttons are often used for destructive actions like deleting user-contributed content.
IconButtonDocumentation.OrganizeIconsAlt: [FR] A document viewer tool bar with pagination icons, zoom icons and resize icons grouped and separeted.
IconButtonDocumentation.OrganizeIconsDoText: [FR] Logically organize icon buttons that have a contextual relationship by keeping related actions together and unrelated actions separated either by white space or dividers.
IconButtonDocumentation.OrganizeIconsDontAlt: [FR] A document viewer tool bar with pagination icons, zoom icons and resize icons together in a row.
IconButtonDocumentation.OrganizeIconsDontText: [FR] Keep unrelated icon button actions together if it is possible to organize groups of actions.
IconButtonDocumentation.CreateIconsDoAlt: [FR] A critical dialog with title “Do you want to delete this file?” along with a description text, a secondary button “Cancel” and critical button “Delete file”.
IconButtonDocumentation.CreateIconsDoText: [FR] Create button groups using the same types of button components.
IconButtonDocumentation.CreateIconsDontAlt: [FR] A critical dialog with title “Do you want to delete this file?” along with a description text, a secondary button “Cancel” and critical icon button “Delete”.
IconButtonDocumentation.CreateIconsDontText: [FR] Create button groups using different types of button components.
IconButtonDocumentation.UseCriticalDestruction: [FR] Use critical icon button for destructive actions
IconButtonDocumentation.UseCriticalDoAlt: [FR] A card with title, “Proof of acceptance” that has a document attached. There is a red critical icon button displaying a trash icon to delete the file.
IconButtonDocumentation.UseCriticalDoText: [FR] Use the critical icon button type to signify actions that are destructive.
IconButtonDocumentation.UseCriticalDontAlt: [FR] A card with title, “Proof of acceptance” that has a document attached. There is a black primary icon button displaying a trash icon to delete the file.
IconButtonDocumentation.UseCriticalDontText: [FR] Use the primary icon button type for an action that is destructive.
IconButtonDocumentation.EasyUnderStandDoAlt: A modal with title “Surname” along with description text, a primary icon button showing an ‘X’ in the corner that allows the user to close the modal.
IconButtonDocumentation.EasyUnderStandDoText: Use the icon button without accompanying text when the icon is common and easily understood.
IconButtonDocumentation.EasyUnderStandDontAlt: A file uploader showing required document with a primary icon button showing a “plus” icon. It is unclear what the plus icon will do.
IconButtonDocumentation.EasyUnderStandDontText: Use the icon button when the icon is ambiguous and may be better understood when accompanied by a label.
IconButtonDocumentation.SpacingText: An icon button group is a set of icon buttons that have a contextual relationship. To create consistency with how these actions are visually related, consistent spacing rules should be followed. Large icon button groups should have 4 pixels between buttons, small icon button groups should have 4 pixels between buttons and extra small icon button groups should have 16 pixels between buttons.
IconButtonDocumentation.AnatomyText: The icon uses the icon component and can be replaced with any Font Awesome icon. The icon button also has a container used for displaying hover, active and focus states around the icon.
IconButtonDocumentation.SpecsImgAlt: Specs displaying the padding and layer measurements within the icon button component. Specs are described in the paragraph below.
IconButtonDocumentation.SpecsText: The extra small button with fixed layout has no pixels of vertical padding and horizontal padding inside the button. The icon has a 16 pixel width and height. The small button with fixed layout has 10 pixels of vertical padding and horizontal padding inside the button. The icon has a 20 pixel width and height. The large button with fluid layout has 14 pixels of vertical padding and horizontal padding inside the button. The icon has a 24 pixel width and height.
IconButtonDocumentation.FigmaDirectionsListItem1: From the “Assets” panel, drag in the “icon-button” component from the Components library.
IconButtonDocumentation.FigmaDirectionsListItem2: In the right panel, configure the properties and variants to meet your needs.
IconButtonDocumentation.FigmaDirectionsListItem3: Never override colours, radius, padding, icon size, etc. This way foundational elements are kept consistent.
IconButtonDocumentation.FigmaDirectionsListItem4: Designers can change the Font Awesome keyword to update the icon in the icon-button to any Font Awesome icon.
IconButtonDocumentation.FigmaDirectionsImgAlt: A screenshot of the design panel from Figma. The design panel displays the configuration options designers can choose from when customizing an icon button.
IconButtonDocumentation.AccessibilityColourText1: Primary icon buttons have a colour contrast ratio of 18.08:1 and passes AAA accessibility standards under WCAG 2.1.
IconButtonDocumentation.AccessibilityColourText2: Critical icon buttons have a colour contrast ratio of 7.03:1 and passes AAA accessibility standards under WCAG 2.1.
IconButtonDocumentation.AccessibilityKeyboardText: Icon buttons are developed using the native HTML button element to ensure interactive elements are keyboard accessible and pass WCAG 2.1 AA conformity.
IconButtonDocumentation.AccessibilityContentItem1: Built for keyboard use, all interactive elements should be focusable and show focus visual indicators to guide the interaction.
IconButtonDocumentation.AccessibilityContentItem2: Since Icon buttons only render an icon, it must pass the aria-label prop, so screen readers can give meaning to the button.
IconButtonDocumentation.AccessibilityContentItem3: Prevent keyboard traps. Every element that can be focused on using the keyboard can be unfocused using the keyboard.
IconButtonDocumentation.LabellingText: Icon buttons should have labels programmatically associated to them so the purpose of the icon button’s action is clear to screen reader users.

Spinner.Title: [FR] Spinner-doc
Spinner.SpinnerAnatomy: [FR] Indicates the state of the loading sequence (active, success, error).
Spinner.LabelAnatomy: [FR] Assistive text that tells the user what content or action is being waited upon.
Spinner.DescriptionAnatomy: [FR] Further explains the label, limited to only be used in the large size.

UsageInFigma.FigmaDirectionsListItem1: [FR] From the “Assets” panel, drag in the “spinner” component from the Components library.
UsageInFigma.FigmaDirectionsImgAlt: A screenshot of the design panel from Figma. The design panel displays the configuration options designers can choose from when customizing the spinner component. These options include size and allow designers choose the spinner size, label, description, states and layout.

Spinner.AccessibilityContentItem3: [FR] Descriptions are provided when content requires additional clarity.
Spinner.AccessibilityContentItem4: [FR] The label and description are placed outside of the spinner and are always visible to the user. The content is presented in a logical reading order.
Spinner.Intro: [FR] Spinners provide a visual cue that an action is processing awaiting a course of change, a result or displaying new content.

DesignGuideLines.UseSpinnerDoTxt: [FR] Use the Spinner if the expected wait time is perceptible — typically more than a second but less than 10 secs.
DesignGuideLines.UseSpinnerDontTxt: [FR] Use Spinner if the action taking place is meant to occur in less than one second.
DesignGuideLines.UseSpinnerDoAlt: [FR] A loading page with the large spinner component in active state positioned in the middle of the page. The label is “Loading your applications” and the description is “Please do not close your browser”.
DesignGuideLines.UseSpinnerDontAlt: [FR] A loading page with the large spinner component in active state positioned in the middle of the page. The label is “Your applications are currently in review...” and the description is “Please do not close your browser”.
DesignGuideLines.InlineLoadingDoTxt: [FR] Use the extra small or small sized spinner for inline loading.
DesignGuideLines.InlineLoadingDontTxt: [FR] Use a large sized spinner for inline loading.
DesignGuideLines.InlineLoadingDoAlt: [FR] A primary button in active state with a cursor above it and a small spinner component in active state on its right side. The primary button’s label is “Sign up”.
DesignGuideLines.InlineLoadingDontAlt: [FR] A primary button in active state with a cursor above it and a large spinner component in active state on its right side. The primary button’s label is “Sign up”.
DesignGuideLines.PageLoadDoTxt: Use the large spinner for full page loading
DesignGuideLines.PageLoadDontTxt: Use the smaller sized spinners for full page loading.
DesignGuideLines.PageLoadDoAlt: A loading page with a large spinner component in active state positioned in the middle of the page The large spinner’s label is “Submitting your application...” and its description says “Please do not close your browser.”
DesignGuideLines.PageLoadDontAlt: A loading page with a small spinner component in active state positioned in the middle of the page. The small spinner’s label is “Submitting your application...” and there is no description.
DesignGuideLines.ShowOneSpinner: Show one spinner at a time
DesignGuideLines.ShowOneSpinnerDoTxt: Show one Spinner at a time and where the content is being updated to showcase where results will appear.
DesignGuideLines.ShowOneSpinnerDontTxt: Show more than one Spinner at a time to avoid an overly-busy interface.
DesignGuideLines.ShowOneSpinnerDoAlt: An application form with 2 form inputs and a cursor hovering over a primary button. The primary buttons label is “Save & Continue”. There is an extra small spinner in active state beside the button.
DesignGuideLines.ShowOneSpinnerDontAlt: An application form with 2 form inputs and a cursor hovering over a primary button. The primary buttons label is “Save & Continue”. The first input forms label is “Primary Office (required)” and its description is “Please select your primary office”. The option “Canada” is selected and there is an extra small sized spinner in active state at the end of the input field. The second input forms label is “Country of Residence” and its description is “Please select your country of residence” The option “Ottawa” is selected and there is a small spinner at the end of the input field.

Spinner.MaxMinWidthImgAlt: Specs displaying the minimum and maximum widths of the spinner component. Widths are described in the paragraph below.
Spinner.MaxMinWidthText: Small spinner has a maximum width of 420 pixels. Extra small spinner has a maximum width of 300 pixels. Large spinner has a maximum width of 500 pixels.

Anatomy.ImgAlt: The parts that makeup the spinner compoennt. The parts are described in the content below.

Specs.ImgAlt: Specs displaying the padding and layer measurements within the spinner component. Specs are described in the paragraph below.
Specs.Text1: The extra small spinner container has a fixed width and a fluid height. The spinner itself has a fixed uniform width and height of 20px. The label is set to fill. There is an 8 pixels of padding between the extra small spinner and the label.
Specs.Text2: The small spinner container has a fixed width and a fluid height. The spinner itself has a fixed uniform width and height of 28px. The label is set to fill. There is an 8 pixels of padding between the small spinner and the label.
Specs.Text3: The large spinner container has a fixed width and a fluid height. The spinner itself has a fixed uniform width and height of 80px. The text container is set to fill and contains the label and description. There is a 16 pixel padding between the large spinner and the text container. In the text container, the label is 36px in height and has an 8px padding above it. The description is  24px in height and has an 8px padding below it. There is a 4px padding between the label and description.

ContentGuideLines.WritingLabelsTxt: Labels are optional content for the spinner component and are available to be shown at each size. Labels make the purpose of the spinner clear.
ContentGuideLines.WritingLabelsDo1: Write labels that are appropriate for the task and clear.
ContentGuideLines.WritingLabelsDont1: Provide vague labels that lack clarity.
ContentGuideLines.WritingLabelsDoAlt1: A modal labeled “Application Management” and a small spinner in active state positioned in the centre of the modal. The spinner’s label is “Loading information...”
ContentGuideLines.WritingLabelsDontAlt1: A modal labeled “Application Management” and a small spinner in active state positioned in the centre of the modal. The spinner’s label is “Waiting...”
ContentGuideLines.WritingLabelsDo2: Keep labels as clear and short as possible.
ContentGuideLines.WritingLabelsDont2: Write longer than necessary labels. Do not truncate labels.
ContentGuideLines.WritingLabelsDoAlt2: A page titled “My Applications” and an extra small spinner in active state positioned to the right of the page title. The extra small spinner’s label is “Connecting to server...”
ContentGuideLines.WritingLabelsDontAlt2: A page titled “My Applications” and an extra small spinner in active state positioned to the right of the page title. The extra small spinner’s label is “Waiting to connect to server to enable access...”
ContentGuideLines.IncludeLabelDo: Include the label with the spinner when the action being waited upon is not obvious.
ContentGuideLines.IncludeLabelDont: Show the spinner without the label if there is ambiguity.
ContentGuideLines.IncludeLabelDoAlt: A modal labeled “Application Management” and a small spinner in active state positioned in the centre of the modal. The spinner’s label is “Loading information...”
ContentGuideLines.IncludeLabelDontAlt: A modal labeled “Application Management” and a small spinner in active state positioned in the centre of the modal. There is no label on the spinner.
ContentGuideLines.NotIncludeLabelDo: Exclude a label when context about what is being loaded is provided by other elements on the page.
ContentGuideLines.NotIncludeLabelDont: Include the label when the user can rely on other information to convey the action that is being loaded.
ContentGuideLines.NotIncludeLabelDoAlt: A primary button in active state with a cursor above it and a small spinner component in active state on its right side. The primary button’s label is “Sign up”.
ContentGuideLines.NotIncludeLabelDontAlt: A primary button in active state with a cursor above it and a small spinner in active state with a label saying “Creating an account” on its right side. The primary button’s label is “Sign up”.
ContentGuideLines.WriteDescTxt: Write a short description to provide further clarity on the action the user is waiting for. Include all the relevant information required, but try to keep the description concise. Descriptions are only available at the large size.
ContentGuideLines.WriteDescDo: Include all additional and relevant information in the description that can provide extra clarity to the user.
ContentGuideLines.WriteDescDont: Include a description when additional instructions or details are not needed to clarify.
ContentGuideLines.WriteDescDoAlt: A loading page with the large spinner component in active state positioned in the middle of the page. The label is “Loading your applications” and the description is “Please do not close your browser”.
ContentGuideLines.WriteDescDontAlt: A loading page with the large spinner component in active state positioned in the middle of the page. The label is “Loading notes, please wait” and the description is “Please wait, loading will be completed momentarily”.

Accessibility.ColorContrastTxt: All elements within the spinner component have a colour contrast ratio of 4.5:1 and passes AA accessibility standards under WCAG 2.1.

Spinner.Validation: If an error is automatically detected, the item that is in error is identified and the error is described to the user in text.

Select.Title: Select
Select.Intro: Selects are most commonly used for users to make an individual selection from a list of options.
